events.originalText: A fire (pictured) severely damaged Notre-Dame de Paris, destroying the cathedral's timber spire and much of the roof.
events.subtitle: Notre-Dame fire
events.headline: Notre-Dame de Paris severely damaged by fire

events.originalText: Dzhokhar and Tamerlan Tsarnaev set off two pressure cooker bombs during the running of the Boston Marathon, killing three people and injuring 264 others.
events.subtitle: Dzhokhar Tsarnaev
events.headline: Boston Marathon bombing kills three, injures 264

events.originalText: At a GATT ministerial meeting in Marrakesh, Morocco, representatives of 123 countries and the European Communities signed an agreement to establish the World Trade Organization.
events.subtitle: General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade
events.headline: World Trade Organization established in Marrakesh

events.originalText: The Hillsborough disaster, a human crush that caused 97 deaths in the worst disaster in British sporting history, occurred during an FA Cup match between Liverpool and Nottingham Forest in Sheffield.
events.subtitle: Hillsborough disaster
events.headline: Hillsborough disaster claims 97 lives during FA Cup match

events.originalText: On Walter O'Malley's initiative, the Los Angeles Dodgers and San Francisco Giants played the first Major League Baseball game on the U.S. West Coast.
events.subtitle: Walter O'Malley
events.headline: First MLB game on U.S. West Coast played by Dodgers and Giants

events.originalText: The Indiaman departed Victoria Coach Station, London, as part of the first UK–India bus service.
events.subtitle: Victoria Coach Station
events.headline: First UK-India bus service departs from London

events.originalText: The Boeing B-52 Stratofortress, a long-range, subsonic, jet-powered, strategic bomber operated by the U.S. Air Force for most of the aircraft's history, made its first flight.
events.subtitle: Boeing B-52 Stratofortress
events.headline: Boeing B-52 Stratofortress makes maiden flight

events.originalText: Jackie Robinson, the first African American to break the baseball color line, played his first game in Major League Baseball.
events.subtitle: Jackie Robinson
events.headline: Jackie Robinson breaks baseball color line in MLB debut

events.originalText: Two Jews were killed near Tulkarm in Mandatory Palestine,  an act widely viewed as the beginning of violence within the Arab revolt.
events.subtitle: 1936 Tulkarm shooting
events.headline: Violence erupts in Mandatory Palestine with killing of two Jews

events.originalText: Torrential rains caused the Mississippi River to break out of its levee system in at least 145 places, resulting in the worst flooding in the history of the United States.
events.subtitle: Mississippi River
events.headline: Mississippi River flooding worst in U.S. history

events.originalText: Ten Japanese-American children were killed in a racially motivated arson attack on a school in Sacramento, California.
events.subtitle: Nihon Shōgakkō fire
events.headline: Racially motivated arson attack kills ten Japanese-American children

events.originalText: U.S. senator John B. Kendrick (pictured) introduced a resolution calling for an investigation of a secret land deal involving U.S. president Warren G. Harding's administration, leading to the Teapot Dome scandal.
events.subtitle: John B. Kendrick
events.headline: Senator calls for investigation into Teapot Dome scandal

events.originalText: More than 1,500 people on the Titanic died when the passenger liner sank after colliding with an iceberg southeast of Newfoundland.
events.subtitle: Titanic
events.headline: Over 1,500 perish in Titanic sinking

events.originalText: The Italian tricolour is adopted as national flag by the newly formed Kingdom of Italy.
events.subtitle: Flag of Italy
events.headline: Italian tricolour adopted as national flag

events.originalText: English poet William Wordsworth and his sister Dorothy encountered a "long belt" of daffodils while walking around Ullswater in the Lake District, inspiring him to pen his best-known work, "I Wandered Lonely as a Cloud".
events.subtitle: William Wordsworth
events.headline: Wordsworth inspired by daffodils to write famous poem

events.originalText: Serse, an opera by Baroque composer George Frideric Handel loosely based on Xerxes I of Persia, premiered in London.
events.subtitle: Serse
events.headline: Handel's opera 'Serse' premieres in London

events.originalText: Thirty Years' War: A Swedish–German army defeated the forces of the Catholic League at the Battle of Rain, mortally wounding their commander Johann Tserclaes, Count of Tilly.
events.subtitle: Thirty Years' War
events.headline: Swedish-German army defeats Catholic League at Battle of Rain

events.originalText: Byzantine–Norman wars: After a siege of almost three years, Italo-Norman forces conquered the city of Bari, the capital of the Catepanate of Italy, ending more than five centuries of Byzantine presence in the region.
events.subtitle: Byzantine–Norman wars
events.headline: Italo-Norman forces conquer Bari, ending Byzantine presence

events.originalText: The final session of the Lateran Council, convened to rectify abuses in the papal electoral process that had led to the elevation of the antipopes Constantine II and Philip, was held in Rome.
events.subtitle: Lateran Council (769)
events.headline: Lateran Council addresses papal election abuses in Rome
